title: Sri Lanka energy minister says adequate fuel stocks will be available over next 10 days
body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – A shipment of Octane 92 petrol was being unloaded in Sri Lanka’s Colombo port Saturday (21) afternoon, with another to be unloaded Sunday, to be followed by a shipment of both Octane 92 and Octane 95 petrol on May 25, power and energy minister Kanchana Wijesekara said.
Wijeskara told reporters on Saturday that two diesel ships and a petrol ship were also due in the next 10 days.
“Two shipments are currently being unloaded. There is no place to unload the third ship at the moment, but it will be once the first two are done,” he said.

Petrol shortages in Sri Lanka worsened over the last few days, with Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe announcing in parliament that no new stocks would be distributed to filling stations until the weekend. Queues that stretched for hundreds of metres were seen around the country regardless.
The energy minister attempted to reassure consumers that there would be no shortage going forward.
“There is no need to fear anything about petrol or diesel. In the next 10 days, two diesel ships and one petrol ship will arrive.

“There is no possibility of a shortage,” he claimed, adding that diesel, auto diesel, and petrol (both octane 92 and 95) will be released to the market in the coming days without interruption. (Colombo/May21/2022)
